channel.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
channel.description:
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-15013860
Now, who was it that said execution punishments are only used when they are 100% certain the guy did it? :|

item.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
item.dc:creator: @akl akl
item.description:
@akl wrote:

Greeny:

I’ve always wondered, I see capital punishment as no real punishment (since they just die, it’s actually more punishing to the families!) do people who think capital punishment is effective believe those that are killed go to suffer in hell? Is that why people are behind it?

I’ve always thought that people generally feel better because, according to them, a “horrible person” is not living on this planet anymore.
But isn’t that just an easy way out? Will not more people like him be there? Are you going to kill them all?
It’s an imperfect world, and an imperfect system…

Read full topic

item.source: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests

item.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:25, topic:415528”]I read the article, and since I (or any of you, probably) don’t know any details of the case beyond that, he probably was guilty. Look at the facts here, 20 years ago, a jury of his peers (12 un-related people), after seeing all the evidence from both sides had absolutely no shread of doubt that he was guilty (otherwise they couldn’t have put in a guilty verdict). Since then he has put in multiple appeals to about anyone and any court that he could, and they have all been denied based on the evidence. His most recent one was all the way to the supreme court, who saw no reason why the verdict should have been overturned. This man had to be either:

  1. Guilty.
  2. The unluckiest bastard on the entire face of the earth.

But my bet is on guilty.

@some points the article made

  1. No conclusive DNA evidence? This was 1989 people, DNA tests weren’t (widely?) used at all.
  2. There was ballistic evidence, the defense said it was flawed, but obviously a jury of 12 and countless judges disagreed.
  3. The ‘Council of Europe’ recommended he not be executed? Mind your own fucking business.
  4. The Pope was on his side? More like the Pope is against capital punishment PERIOD. He also would have been against the killing of the racist bastard that happened in Texas that day as well.[/quote]

Hello logical fallacies!

Niall dealt with those quite effectively.

Because the United States never makes suggestions (or more) about how other countries should be treating their citizens, right?
Something I can definitely agree with, don't even need to elaborate on the "(or more)" although it might be needed if the stench of hypocrisy in his claim didn't quite waft over some people's noses. I don't think any of us really need to though, do we. :rolleyes:

I’ve always wondered, I see capital punishment as no real punishment (since they just die, it’s actually more punishing to the families!) do people who think capital punishment is effective believe those that are killed go to suffer in hell? Is that why people are behind it?

Read full topic
item.source: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests

item.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I read the article, and since I (or any of you, probably) don’t know any details of the case beyond that, he probably was guilty.

I actually agree with you. There is a good chance he was.

However, that’s exactly the point. Chance isn’t good enough. If you’re going to have capital punishment, you have to be DAMN SURE beyond any reasonable doubt that somebody is guilty before executing them.

The wife of the guy who was murdered accidentally summed it up best, she said “he has had 20 years to prove his innocence and hasn’t”.

Yep, guilty until proven innocent.

Read full topic
item.source: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests

item.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Davidi2:

do you want??? Do you want them punished?

No, I don’t want to punish them.
I want them to get help. show people that murder isn’t a good idea, and protect people from them for a reasonable time. Both killing them and lock them up like you to is terrible, that is the reason we criticize both.

Speaking of terrorist magnets. Maybe US should stop acting like a dick, then less people would feel the urge to attack them.

Read full topic
item.source: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests

item.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I read the article, and since I (or any of you, probably) don’t know any details of the case beyond that, he probably was guilty.

tl;dr “I read this article and can conclude he was probably guilty”

Moparisthebest:

Look at the facts here, 20 years ago, a jury of his peers (12 un-related people), after seeing all the evidence from both sides had absolutely no shread of doubt that he was guilty (otherwise they couldn’t have put in a guilty verdict).

look at the bigger picture, the trial 20 years ago was based primarily on 9 eye witnesses accounts, since then however 7 of the 9 witnesses have changed or removed their testimony and have claimed that the police coerced them

and what evidence was there for the case? no murder weapon was ever recovered and there was no DNA evidence linking davis to the murder, even one of the pieces of evidence(some blood on a pair of davis’ shorts) was reviewed in 2008 by a DNA expert and in 2010 a federal court concluded from the study that the shorts in no way linked davis to the murder and couldn’t even be sure that the substance on the shorts was even blood

here’s a fun fact, sylvester coles was one of the 2 witnesses that didn’t change their testimony, and sylvester coles was never treated as a suspect, after all why should he? I mean, he was at the scene of the crime for a start, he had the same type of pistol used in the shooting and there were testimonies that it was coles who started the fight with the homeless person and even pistol whipped the homeless person as he walked away which eventually lead to the police officer, who was shot, to intervene, that’s no reason to treat someone as a suspect right? in all seriousness though the police never checked on coles despite coles having a .38, the same weapon as the murder weapon which was never found, and in one of the appeal courts 9 people who did not originally testify sworn that coles was the shooter and the judge dismissed it

another fun fact is, when the original 9 eye witnesses who were asked to re-enact the crime a week after the murder, coles was one of them and was treated as an innocent bystander while davis picture was all over the news and was in jail at the time

Moparisthebest:

Since then he has put in multiple appeals to about anyone and any court that he could, and they have all been denied based on the evidence.

of course he placed multiple appeals, he was on death row and maintained his innocence until he died, people tend to appeal their crime when they claim their innocence

Moparisthebest:

His most recent one was all the way to the supreme court, who saw no reason why the verdict should have been overturned.

interesting fact, the supreme court took unusually long to come to a decision, 4 hours for the 11th hour decision, and haven’t commented on why they took this long, it’s nothing substantial just interesting

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:25, topic:415528”]@some points the article made

  1. No conclusive DNA evidence? This was 1989 people, DNA tests weren’t (widely?) used at all.[/quote]

that doesn’t mean shit, DNA lasts a LONG time and examination of DNA evidence from OLDDDDD 30-40 year old crimes has changed the outcome of other cases, people are often proven innocent based on recent examination of old DNA evidence and a lot of old unsolved crimes have been solved due to recent DNA examination, and evidence from crimes is USUALLY locked up for years in a police warehouse, there is no issue of re-examining old evidence at all

and my understanding of this case is no DNA evidence found ever linked davis to the crime and recent studies from 2008 confirm this

Moparisthebest:

2. There was ballistic evidence, the defense said it was flawed, but obviously a jury of 12 and countless judges disagreed.

hate to bring up coles again but both coles and davis had a .38 which was the type of gun used in the murder, and the murder weapon was never found, the police never investigated coles .38 and the ballistics evidence was just the shells and bullets at the crime scene from what I remember

I’ve casually followed this case for a few weeks and I don’t really know if davis was guilty or not, but what I’ve learned is that the original investigation was rushed and poorly conducted and new testimonies and re-examination of old evidence was never taken into account in the appeals, it’s extremely shocking that without any concrete evidence, substantial doubt and only 2 testimonies can get someone executed in america despite many americans claiming people are only ever executed when there is no doubt that they are guilty

and now for some not-so comic relief, I give you an image I found on reddit(that was probably found on 4chan) - http://i.imgur.com/W2F4S.png

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“tL, post:26, topic:415528”]Oh we’re sorry. We forgot we should all talk in step with each other if we’re not of your opinion.

Guys, we need to align our opinions together because we’re not all saying the same thing, even if we share some of the same opinions.[/quote]I was directing it at people that were going against themselves (though your quote was the easiest and shortest to put in)

And @ Yakman, what would you have them do instead? At least they’re being productive instead of lolling around all day.

item.source: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests

item.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:24, topic:415528”]Find one extreme case -> apply to entire system -> ??? -> profit

I’m sure none of your systems ever have extreme cases, right? Obviously no one here supports this, American or not, so how about you shove it up the judges butt instead of applying it to the entire system

Honestly, this is almost as stupid as the guys over at moparscape saying ‘obviously we shouldnt be building skyscrapers anymore because they are terrorist magnets!’

To add onto whether we should have the death penalty or not, you guys need to make up your fucking minds. One minute you’re saying ‘YOU GUYS SHOULDNT GIVE THEM THE EASY WAY OUT’, then you say ‘YOUR PRISONS SUCK’! Which do you want??? Do you want them punished (not some fairy cruise with lots of leisure time and do fuck-all what you want), or do you want the REALLY bad ones gone?[/quote]

Oh we’re sorry. We forgot we should all talk in step with each other if we’re not of your opinion.

Guys, we need to align our opinions together because we’re not all saying the same thing, even if we share some of the same opinions.

Moparisthebest:

3. The ‘Council of Europe’ recommended he not be executed? Mind your own fucking business.

Because the United States never makes suggestions (or more) about how other countries should be treating their citizens, right?

Read full topic

item.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I read the article, and since I (or any of you, probably) don’t know any details of the case beyond that, he probably was guilty. Look at the facts here, 20 years ago, a jury of his peers (12 un-related people), after seeing all the evidence from both sides had absolutely no shread of doubt that he was guilty (otherwise they couldn’t have put in a guilty verdict). Since then he has put in multiple appeals to about anyone and any court that he could, and they have all been denied based on the evidence. His most recent one was all the way to the supreme court, who saw no reason why the verdict should have been overturned. This man had to be either:

  1. Guilty.
  2. The unluckiest bastard on the entire face of the earth.

But my bet is on guilty.

@some points the article made

  1. No conclusive DNA evidence? This was 1989 people, DNA tests weren’t (widely?) used at all.
  2. There was ballistic evidence, the defense said it was flawed, but obviously a jury of 12 and countless judges disagreed.
  3. The ‘Council of Europe’ recommended he not be executed? Mind your own fucking business.
  4. The Pope was on his side? More like the Pope is against capital punishment PERIOD. He also would have been against the killing of the racist bastard that happened in Texas that day as well.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2

@davidi2 wrote:

Find one extreme case -> apply to entire system -> ??? -> profit

I’m sure none of your systems ever have extreme cases, right? Obviously no one here supports this, American or not, so how about you shove it up the judges butt instead of applying it to the entire system

Honestly, this is almost as stupid as the guys over at moparscape saying ‘obviously we shouldnt be building skyscrapers anymore because they are terrorist magnets!’

To add onto whether we should have the death penalty or not, you guys need to make up your fucking minds. One minute you’re saying ‘YOU GUYS SHOULDNT GIVE THEM THE EASY WAY OUT’, then you say ‘YOUR PRISONS SUCK’! Which do you want??? Do you want them punished (not some fairy cruise with lots of leisure time and do fuck-all what you want), or do you want the REALLY bad ones gone?

item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

[quote=“Frell, post:14, topic:415528”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=517473.msg3758859#msg3758859 date=1316716872]

Even if he was guilty, murdering him is not a solution.
[/quote]Don’t be so sure! I think Americans like “the final solution”

C WUT I DID DER

Yea cause we don’t have to pay to feed a 100% guilty murderer.[/quote]

You don’t need to feed them anything you ignorant fool.

You guys just force them to work for you.

Inhumane scum.

item.source: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests

item.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

The rest of the criminals need help, a prison sentence won’t do that much.

There is many nice solutions very small crimes that don’t include prison. Like community service and electronic shackles. But you shouldn’t use that against murder of course. Prison sentence doesn’t work alone, but getting help inside prison and when they get out is the solution. The government should secure a home and a job for the inmate at the release. That could prevent them from doing stupid things again. Too bad “the great capitalist United States” aren’t able to create enough workplaces.

Read full topic
item.source: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests

item.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:19, topic:415528”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=517473.msg3758851#msg3758851 date=1316716206]
I agree with Bowser jr, the death penalty might seem like a great way to get rid of criminals, but it’s final. Besides, a life penalty isn’t that more expensive, and it’s definitely more humane.
[/quote]
You know a solution that is less expensive and more humane?
Limited prison sentence, and bringing the prisoners back into the society with rehabilitation.[/quote]

I’m not saying we should put criminals away for life. But it’s better than executing them. There is a tiny group of criminals who can’t stop committing crimes, and agree that they are, and always will be, a danger to society. This specific group should be put in a special institution, where they can live a decent life while being locked up. So an internally open institution that’s closed from the outside world.

The rest of the criminals need help, a prison sentence won’t do that much.

Read full topic

You know a solution that is less expensive and more humane?
Limited prison sentence, and bringing the prisoners back into the society with rehabilitation.

Newty:

Fuck our justice system; it is beyond corrupt and it is time for somebody to step up and fix it.

The same goes for your political and finance system.

item.title: Troy Davis executed in Georgia amid innocence protests
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Newty, post:16, topic:415528”]So this man who was /probably/ innocent was sentenced to death and then executed despite there being a reasonable doubt that he was innocent yet a couple of policeman can beat a homeless man to death WITH irrefutable video evidence and only be charged with manslaughter and will probably only face a couple of years in prison.

cbsnews.com

2 cops charged in beating death of homeless man

One officer faces murder charge in vicious beating and electrocution of mentally ill man in July; 6 administrative leave

This is the final straw for me. Fuck our justice system; it is beyond corrupt and it is time for somebody to step up and fix it.[/quote]

The problem is that laws differ state wise, and so do punishments.

Personally, I’m against trial by peers, as a judge only looks at the evidence, and a jury is easily influenced by the presentation of the evidence.

Read full topic
